questions.question: Apoyas la igualdad en el matrimonio entre parejas homosexuales y lesbianas?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Actualmente apoya el matrimonio homosexual y ha respaldado la legalización nacional del matrimonio homosexual por el Tribunal Supremo
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Votó en contra de la Ley de Defensa del Matrimonio cuando estaba en el House of Representatives en 1996.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: En una declaración en el 2013, Clinton revertió su posición anterior sobre el matrimonio entre homosexuales, diciendo: "Yo apoyo el matrimonio homosexual personalmente y como ley."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Como Primera Dama, Clinton apoyó la Ley de Defensa del Matrimonio, que se opone a la legalización de los matrimonios homosexuales.

questions.question: Apoyas el Patriot Act, que permite la vigilancia secreta de ciudadanos Estadounidenses sin permiso de la corte?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders reafirmó su oposición contra el Patriot Act en el 2015, diciendo que debemos "proteger al pueblo estadounidense del peligro muy real de ataques terroristas sin poner en peligro los derechos constitucionales que nos hacen un país libre."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Votó en contra del Patriot Act en el 2001.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton mantuvo su posición con respecto al Patriot Act en el 2015, diciendo: "Creo que era necesario para asegurarse de que hemos sido capaces desde de 9/11para poner en marcha la seguridad que necesitábamos."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Votó a favor del Patriot Act en el 2001.

questions.question: Crees que la marihuana debería ser descriminilaizada a nivel federal?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: En el 2015, Sanders introdujo una ley para acabar con la prohibición federal de la marihuana, diciendo: “Demasiados estadounidenses han visto sus vidas destruidas por tener antecedentes penales como resultado del uso de la marihuana. Eso está mal."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Debido a que el debate se limita a la marihuana médica hasta hace poco tiempo, ninguno de los candidatos tiene un historial extensivo en este tema.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton no apoya descriminalización federal, pero sí apoya una política más relajada para la marihuana medicinal. Sugirió en el 2015 que reclasificaría la marihuana como una substancia controlada de Categoría II en vez de una categoría mas severa, Categoría I, con el fin de promover la investigación sobre los usos médicos de la droga.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Debido a que el debate se limita a la marihuana médica hasta hace poco tiempo, ninguno de los candidatos tiene un historial extensivo en este tema.

questions.question: Apoyas el oleoducto Keystone XL, que llevaría petróleo con fuertes emisiones de Canadá a las refinerías de Estados Unidos?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: En una entrevista en el 2015 con Chuck Todd en Meet the Press, Sanders dijo: "Desde el primer día, Me opuse al oleoducto Keystone porque creo que si usted es serio sobre el cambio climático, no motivas la excavación y transporte de petróleo sucio."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: En una discusión en el 2013, Sanders dijo la tecnología de energía renovable "es el futuro, no el petróleo, y por eso el oleoducto Keystone deberá ser derrotado."
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Anunció en Septiembre del 2015 que estaba en contra del oleoducto.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Como Secretaria de Estado, Clinton dijo que “estaba inclinada” a aprobar el oleoductor, diciendo: "vamos a depender de petróleo sucio del Golfo, o petróleo sucio de Canadá."

questions.question: Cree usted que las mujeres deben tener el derecho legal a un salario igual al de los hombres?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: La campaña de Sanders dice: "Es una vergüenza nacional que las mujeres sólo ganen 78 centavos por cada dólar que gana un hombre. Como presidente, el senador Sanders firmará la Ley de Paycheck Fairness."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Copatrocinó la Ley de Paycheck Fairness en el 2007, que enforzaría las prohibiciones contra la discriminación sexual en el pago de salarios.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Hablando en una campaña en San Francisco en el 2015, Clinton dijo: “Es el momento de tener la igualdad de salarios de una vez por todas.”
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Copatrocinó la Ley de Paycheck Fairness mientras que en el Senado en el 2005 yd promovió la legislación sobre igualdad de remuneración, mientras candidata a la presidencia en el 2008.

questions.question: Cree en un sistema de salud de estilo europeo (de un solo pagador) que garantice la cobertura universal para todos los Estadounidenses?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: En un evento en el 2015, Sanders dijo: "Necesitamos ampliar Medicare para que cubra a cada hombre, mujer y niño como un programa nacional de salud de un solo pagador."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Sanders, un defensor de la salud universal por toda su vida, también fue el primer Senador en presentar ese sistema de salud en el senado en el 2013.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: En el segundo debate Democrata, Clinton dijo en vez de implementar un sistema de salud de un solo pagador, deberíamos "apoyar la Ley de Affordable Care, mejorarla, y hacerla el modelo que sabemos que puede ser."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: En una entrevista en el 2008, Clinton dijo: "He pensado en esto, como ya habrás adivinado, por 15 años y nunca he considerado seriamente un sistema de un solo pagador."

questions.question: Cree que su salario debe tener una tasa mayor de impuestos que las inversiones?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: El plan de impuestos de Sanders "aumentaría impuestors a inversiones y dividendos con la misma tasa al salario... De esa manera recaudaría mas de $500 mil millones durante la próxima década."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Votó en contra la continuación de bajos impuestos para inversiones y dividendos en el 2005, indicando que estos recortes de impuestos son "un ejemplo del President Bush y el liderazgo Republicano haciendo todo por ayudar a gente que no necesita ayuda."
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton ha tomado una posición intermedia y presentó un plan de subir impuestos a inversiones a corto plazo, pero dejando las de largo plazo en la baja taza de interés de 23.8%.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: En un debate en el 2008, Clinton dijo: "No lo subiría [el impuesto a la inversion] a mas de 20% si es que lo subo en lo absoluto. No lo elevaria mas de lo que fue durante la previa administración Clinton."

questions.bernieSandersPositionText: "No creo que cualquier persona sensata estaría en desacuerdo que la invasión de Irak llevó a la inestabilidad masiva que estamos viendo en este momento," Sanders dijo en un debate reciente.
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Votó en contra de la guerra en Irak en el 2002, diciendo: "Guerra debe ser el último recurso de las relaciones internacionales, no el primera... Quién governará Iral después de sacar a Saddam Hussein? Y qué papel jugaremos los EE.UU. en una subsiguiente guerra civil que podría desarrollarse en ese país?"
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: In her 2014 book, Hard Choices, Clinton said that her vote was a mistake. She wrote: "Many Senators came to wish they had voted against the resolution. I was one of them."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Voted to authorize the Iraq War in 2002. Clinton said at the time: "Any vote that might lead to war should be hard, but I cast it with conviction.” Defended her vote when running against Obama in 2008.
questions.question: Do you agree with Congress' 2002 decision to authorize the Iraq War?
Apoya la perforación de petróleo a poca distancia de la costa en el Ártico y el Golfo de México?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Recently co-sponsored the Keep It In the Ground Act, a bill that would "ban offshore drilling for oil and gas in the Arctic and the Atlantic and would stop new leases for offshore drilling in the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Introduced legislation in 2010 to ban offshore drilling in the Pacific and Atlantic oceans and along Florida’s gulf coastline.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Opposes Obama's plan to conduct drilling in the Arctic, but has not come out against offshore drilling in general.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Voted for the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act in 2006, which opened an additional 8 million acres of the Gulf of Mexico to oil and gas drilling.

questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Speaking about Glass Steagall in 2015, Sanders said: "We not only must reinstate this important law, but we also have to break up the too-big-to-fail financial institutions in this country. If an institution is too big to fail, it is too big to exist."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Voted against the Financial Services Modernization Act of 1999, which repealed Glass-Steagall and allowed large financial institutions to consolidate.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: In a 2015 campaign stop, Clinton said that she would not reinstate Glass-Steagall as president.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: No record of having taken a position on this issue before the 2016 presidential campaign.
questions.question: Apoya el restablecimiento de la Ley Glass-Steagall, que impediría el comercio de alto riesgo con el dinero que deposita en el banco?
Do you support the No Child Left Behind Act, signed into law by President George Bush in 2002, which ties school funding to performance on national standardized tests?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: In 2015 Sanders wrote: “I voted against No Child Left Behind in 2001, and continue to oppose the bill’s reliance on high-stakes standardized testing to direct draconian interventions. In my view, No Child Left Behind ignores several important factors in a student’s academic performance, specifically the impact of poverty, access to adequate health care, mental health, nutrition, and a wide variety of supports that children in poverty should have access to."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Sanders voted against the final version of the bill in 2001.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: In 2015 Clinton wrote: "When the No Child Left Behind Act was enacted, I viewed it as a historic promise between the federal government and educators. I hoped that it would lead to a greater sense of shared responsibility for our schools’ success. Unfortunately, that promise was largely broken because schools struggled to meet the mandates imposed by the law and the implementation at the federal level was problematic."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Clinton voted in favor of the final version of the bill in 2001.

questions.question: Do you believe the United States should build a fence along its border with Mexico to insulate itself from illegal immigration?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: In 2015 speech, Sanders said that he stood by his earlier immigration policy that opposes "tying immigration reform to the building of a border fence."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Voted against building a fence along the Mexican border in 2006.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: When asked in 2015 what she would do about securing the Mexican border from illegal immigration, Clinton said: "I voted numerous times when I was a senator to spend money to build a barrier to try to prevent illegal immigrants from coming in, and I do think you have to control your borders.”
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Voted to build a fence along the Mexican border in 2006.

questions.question: Do you believe that the death penalty should be abolished?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Has called, as recently as October, for abolishing the death penalty on the federal level.
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Has consistently voted against the death penalty throughout his career.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Continues to support the death penalty.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Has consistently voted in favor of the death penalty throughout her career.

questions.bernieSandersPositionText: In a 2015 petition, Sanders wrote: "The Trans-Pacific Partnership is a disastrous trade agreement designed to protect the interests of the largest multi-national corporations at the expense of workers, consumers, the environment and the foundations of American democracy."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Sanders has been an opponent of the Trans-Pacific Partnership since its introduction into Congress.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: In an October 2015 interview, Clinton said that she no longer supports the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Clinton has advocated for the Trans-Pacific Partnership on at least forty occasions in the last two years.
questions.question: Do you support the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which lowers trade barriers, but weakens regulation of multi-national corporations?
Do you believe that tuition for public colleges should be free?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders introduced the College for All Act in the Senate in 2015, which would eliminate undergraduate tuition at 4-year public colleges and universities.
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Neither candidate had taken a position on this issue before the 2016 campaign.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: In August 2015, Clinton proposed a plan that would help students at public colleges gradudate debt-free, but would still require family financial contribution and student employment.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Neither candidate had taken a position on this issue before the 2016 campaign.

questions.question: Do you believe in a federal ban on assault weapons?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Voted in April 2013 for a ban on assault weapons and expanded background checks on gun buyers.
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Voted in 1993 to ban semi-automatic assault weapons.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: According to her campaign website, Clinton "supports reinstating the assault weapons ban."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Co-sponsored a 2003 bill in the Senate to renew the 1993 assault weapons ban.

questions.question: Do you believe that the prison at Guantanamo Bay should be closed and its detainees transported to US prisons?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders still supports closing Guantanamo and voted against the National Defense Authorization Act in 2015, which blocked the transfer of prisoners to the U.S.
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Voted to allow the transfer of Guantanamo detainees to America in 2007.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: In a 2013 memo written just before her resignation as Secretary of State, Clinton advocated for closing Guantanamo and initiating detainee transfers for "pre-trial detention, trial, and sentences."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Voted to block the transfer of Guantanamo detainees to America in 2007.

questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Introduced legislation in 2015 to raise the federal minimum wage to $15. In the second democratic debate, he said: “You have no disposable income when you are make 10, 12 bucks an hour. When we put money into the hands of working people, they're going to go out and buy goods, they're going to buy services and they're going to create jobs...”
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Neither candidate had taken a position on this issue before the 2016 campaign.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Supports a $12 minimum wage at the federal level, saying that while some localities can choose to go higher, "what you can do in L.A. or in New York may not work in other places."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Neither candidate had taken a position on this issue before the 2016 campaign.
questions.question: Do you support raising the federal minimum wage to $12 or $15 an hour?
Do you support federal funding for family planning and contraceptives?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders' campaign platform states that he would "expand, not cut, funding for Planned Parenthood, the Title X family planning program, and other initiatives that protect women’s health, access to contraception, and the availability of a safe and legal abortion."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Co-sponsored the Prevention First Act in 2009, which aimed to increase access to women's health care.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton's campaign platform states that she would "stand up to Republican attempts to defund Planned Parenthood, which would restrict access to critical health care services, like cancer screenings, contraception, and safe, legal abortion."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Co-sponsored the Prevention First Act in 2009, which aimed to increase access to women's health care.

questions.bernieSandersPositionText: In a recent statement to the Washington Post, Sanders said: “I oppose, at this point, a unilateral American no-fly-zone in Syria, which could get us more deeply involved in that horrible civil war and lead to a never-ending U.S. entanglement in that region.”
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: While Sanders expressed "serious concerns" about deepening American involvement in Syria in 2013, he did not take a clear position on a no-fly-zone at the time.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton supports increased military involvement in Syria, including the establishment of a no-fly-zone.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: While Clinton considered the idea of a no-fly-zone as Secretary of State, her position on the issue was not reported until recently.
questions.question: Do you believe that the United States should escalate its involvement in the Syrian conflict by instituting a no-fly-zone?

questions.bernieSandersPositionText: In a 2015 speech, Sanders said that he "continue[s] to be a strong supporter of the DREAM Act, which would offer the opportunity of permanent residency and eventual citizenship to young people who were brought to the United States as children."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Voted for the DREAM Act while in the Senate in 2007.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton's campaign platform states her continued support for the DREAM Act and for "comprehensive immigration reform that provides a full and equal path to citizenship."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Co-sponsored the DREAM Act while in the Senate in 2003.
questions.question: Do you support the DREAM Act, which would offer a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants who arrived in the US as minors?
Do you believe in federally mandated background checks for individuals who want to purchase firearms?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: When asked in a 2015 interview what should be done about gun control, Sanders said: "For a start, universal instant background checks. Nobody should have a gun who has a criminal background."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Voted against the Brady Bill in 1993, saying instead that states should individually set background-check policies.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton's campaign platform states that she would "advocate for comprehensive federal background check legislation" and "reduce unlawful gun transfers to dangerous individuals" as President.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Clinton has been a longtime supporter of the Brady Bill, which imposes a five-day waiting period on background checks for firearm purchases.

questions.question: Do you support fracking techniques used to extract natural gas from the earth?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders continues to oppose fracking. His climate change policy proposal states: "Fracking threatens our air and water... We have clean energy solutions to climate change, and fracking is not one of them."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Sanders advocated for restrictions on fracking as part of The Climate Protection Act that he sponsored in 2013.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Since July 2015, Clinton has supported phasing out fracking on public lands with some exceptions, but noted that the U.S. needs to balance its aspiration to be an energy superpower with the need to address climate change.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Clinton supported fracking in Bulgaria and other European countries while Secretary of State.

questions.question: Do you believe that mandatory minimum sentences should be ended for non-violent drug offenses?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders' campaign platform states: "We need to turn back from the failed 'War on Drugs' and eliminate mandatory minimums which result in sentencing disparities between black and white people."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Co-sponsored legislation in the Senate in 2010 to end harsher sentences for crack cocaine posession.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton stated that as President she would "reduce mandatory minimum sentences for nonviolent drug offenses by cutting them in half."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Co-sponsored the Fair Sentencing Act in 2007, which reduced the sentencing disparity between crack and powder cocaine offenses.

questions.question: Do you support raising income taxes on the wealthiest Americans?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Sanders said in the second Democratic debate: "We are going to end the absurdity, as Warren Buffet often reminds us, that billionaires pay an effective tax rate lower than nurses or truck drivers. That makes no sense at all. There has to be real tax reform, and the wealthiest and large corporations will pay when I'm president."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Sanders opposed the Bush tax cuts in 2001 and 2003, and sponsored a 2008 bill to increase the tax rate for individuals earning over $1 million.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Clinton said in the first Democratic debate: "Right now, the wealthy pay too little and the middle class pays too much... the wealthy will have to pay their fair share."
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Clinton opposed the Bush tax cuts in 2001 and 2003, and voted to raise taxes on individuals earning more than $1 million.

questions.question: Do you believe that a significant portion of our prison system should be run by privately owned companies?
questions.bernieSandersPositionText: Introduced a bill to ban private prisons, saying: "We need to start treating prisoners like human beings. Private companies should not be profiting from their incarceration."
questions.bernieSandersRecordText: Neither candidate has a substantial record on this issue.
questions.hillaryClintonPositionText: Called for a ban on private prisons and returned money that had been donated to her campaign by these groups in October of 2015.
questions.hillaryClintonRecordText: Neither candidate has a substantial record on this issue.
